titleStmt.title: Minutes of Historical Advisory Committee Meeting, March 1992
HAC Meeting Minutes, 1992

div.head: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HISTORICAL DIPLOMATIC DOCUMENTATION March 26-27, 1992

list.item: Deputy Assistant Secretary of State G. Alfred Kennedy
Joe H. Chaddic, Chief, Historical Documents Review Division (FPC/HDR)
John T. Fawcett, Assistant Archivist for Presidential Libraries

div.p: The meeting convened at 9:30 a.m. Deputy Assistant Secretary for the Bureau of Public Affairs Kennedy welcomed the Committee and said the Department of State was working on implementing the new Foreign Relations legislation. He noted that the goals of the law were the same as the goals of the agreed Action Plan which went into effect in February 1991. He said that the law as well as a recent speech by CIA Director Gates denoted a “new spirit of openness in Washington.”
He described what had been accomplished by the Historical Office:

item.p: 1) an approved Charter of the Advisory Committee;
2) a draft inter-agency agreement on access; and
3) a long-term declassification and production schedule to reach the 30-year line.

div.p: He concluded by noting that the Historical Office and the Department of State want the Committee’s advice on these and other matters in its purview.
Prof. Bradford Perkins nominated Prof. Warren Kimball as chairman of the Advisory Committee; the nomination was seconded by Prof. Emily Rosenberg. The Committee unanimously approved.

Kimball called on William Z. Slany for the Historian’s report. Slany started by discussing procedural matters: contracts for Committee members; note-taking and minutes of the meeting; and security clearances. The clearances are not yet completed, but all are entitled to Top Secret clearances and additional clearances would be required by at least some members of the Committee in order to fulfill their duties.

Kimball asked about the reporting requirements called for in the legislation. Slany indicated that Secretary Baker had delegated to Under Secretary for Management Rogers, who had delegated to Assistant Secretary Tutwiler his authority to choose Committee members. The Committee’s report with recommendations regarding the Foreign Relations series would go to Assistant Secretary Tutwiler. The Committee’s report regarding the Department’s records would go to Under Secretary Rogers.

Kimball, however, was reluctant to cede direct access to Secretary Baker, but Kennedy repeated that Baker had delegated authority to Rogers for receipt of reports of many of the Department’s advisory committees.

Prof. Anna Nelson wished to clarify that the newly-constituted Advisory Committee on Historical Diplomatic Documentation had authority to review and make recommendations on all the Department of State records and not just those used in the Foreign Relations series. Both Slany and Kennedy confirmed this.
Perkins reminded the Committee members of their obligation to report on the Committee’s work to their respective organizations.

Slany continued with his report on the implementation of the legislation in the Department of State. He noted the coordination within the Department and with other agencies, including the CIA and the NSC, for access to documentation. By April 25, the Department of State must have access agreements with all agencies that will provide documentation for the Foreign Relations series. These agreements call for the designation of liaison officers or the implementation of procedures within agency historical offices to facilitate access.

Perkins began a discussion of possible conflicts regarding access between P. L. 102-138 and regulations governing access to documentation at the National Archives and, particularly, the Presidential Libraries. John Fawcett, Assistant Archivist for Presidential Libraries, explained the statutory obligation for access to Presidential Libraries, and assured the Committee that there was no conflict. The Committee members agreed that they would like to see the agreements with the agencies when they are completed. If the Committee sees an intent to evade the legislation, then it must decide how to respond.

Kimball inquired whether the ambiguity of language in Section 404 (b)(3) of P. L. 102-138 could be interpreted to exclude from declassification an almost indefinite amount of documentation. Slany explained that this section would be interpreted in accord with existing declassification guidelines in Executive Order 12356 and would not cause additional restriction of documents.

Slany emphasized the big question: Can the 30-year line deadline be met under current guidelines? The task of reaching the 30-year line in 5 years is enormous: 74 volumes, print and microfiche, must be produced by 1996. Of these, 14 will be produced this year; 39-40 will be cleared in the next 3-4 years; and 16 volumes for the Kennedy years are being compiled. The Department realized that this ambitious schedule called for in the Action Plan of February 1991, would be very difficult to realize.

In considering whether to increase the staff size of the Office of the Historian commensurately with the increased workload, Slany expressed the opinion that staff size was not the key to this issue, and that in any case the Department’s historical staff was uniquely competent to complete the task. He reiterated that the problem was foremost a managerial one.

Slany asked for the Committee’s advice and/or endorsement of the overall scope of the series. We must all recognize that the scope of the records is much greater than can be included in the series. The Historical Office asks for advice on what can or should be left out.

At this time, access to records determines to some degree what is included in the volumes. He would like the Committee’s input and involvement at any level -- documents, volumes, subseries -- regarding the scope of the series.

Kimball asked if the production schedule had been circulated to other agencies. Slany replied that the Department of State does not yet have other agencies’ agreement on the schedule. He repeated that the Department was seeking written agreements with agencies by April 25. Rosenberg requested status reports on these interagency access agreements by April 25 as well as copies of the agreements.

Nelson noted that it might be very useful to private researchers if the production schedule were circulated to the professional societies to publish in their newsletters. The target dates in the schedule might help researchers in making FOI requests.

Prof. George Herring recalled that some years ago delays at the Government Printing Office were causing problems. Deputy Historian Glenn LaFantasie noted that the Department of State was revising its arrangements with the GPO and exploring the possibility of a waiver. He was also instituting new procedures to improve efficiency within the Office.
LaFantasie reported three future trends in the Foreign Relations series:

item.p: 1) A necessary reduction in coverage: Johnson administration volumes would be 800 print pages long.
2) A reduction in the number of volumes: there were 75 volumes covering the Eisenhower administration but only about 30 for the Kennedy years and 33 for the Johnson administration.
3) Beginning with the Johnson administration, microfiche would not be used to publish.

div.p: The Committee was concerned about the elimination of microfiche, with the significantly reduced published documentation. Slany reminded them that compiling, declassifying, and publishing such large amounts of documentation, even in microfiche, was virtually impossible under the legislative timetable.
The meeting recessed at 10:45 for a coffee break.
Prof. Betty Glad questioned how it would be possible to reconcile the planned smaller scope of the Foreign Relations series with the legislative mandate for the series to be complete and accurate.

LaFantasie provided an overview of proposed modified research methodology for the series. He pointed out that Department historians will have to be more efficient in the research. This will require more careful planning and greater selectivity during the research and coordination among the staff to avoid duplicating research in particular files. The planning for the content of volumes will have to be adjusted during the course of research as compilers become more knowledgeable about particular issues and about the historical record. The legislative mandate for the series to be accurate represents a formidable intellectual challenge. The Office will have to devise selection principles and will welcome advice from the Committee about this. The series will have to provide in the front matter detailed bibliographical information about the historical record and also explain why certain issues have been documented and why others have not. Meeting the legislative mandate will require adopting improved documentary editing methodology, much of which has become standard in the profession.
Kimball suggested that the Historian’s Office provide something in writing on this concept.

Glad thought it would be useful to examine a particular volume planned for the Johnson administration. Kimball said the Committee needed to look at the philosophical issues in planning the series, i.e., what is the audience for the series? Nelson suggested that an examination of a planned Johnson volume would lead to an understanding of general principles.

Rosenberg stated that it would be difficult for the Committee to examine the content outlines for the Johnson volumes unless there was some form of presentation by experts, such as the compilers. The Committee should focus on how this process could be done for the Johnson volumes before the research plans had been fully developed.

Kimball said that perhaps the Committee should divide itself into subcommittees to study the Johnson volume outlines and present its findings to the full Committee. He inquired when the right time would be for the Committee to get involved in evaluating the plans for the Johnson volumes. Slany responded that now is the time to determine if any major issues had been omitted from the outline.
Glad moved that the Advisory Committee discuss the content outline for the Johnson volume entitled “Confrontation in Southeast Asia” as a test sample. Nelson seconded the motion.

LaFantasie said that a substantive discussion could not be undertaken at present. The outlines for the Johnson volumes are preliminary; not all volumes had been scoped out by the historians. Rosenberg stated that it was better to discuss the overall layout of the volumes and determine if supplements would be required. Slany said that the concept of having the compilers prepare content analyses of planned volumes was part of the Department’s Action Plan of February 1991. Perhaps these could be prepared by the next meeting.

Anne Van Camp stated that the Committee needed to differentiate between process and philosophy. It was essential to understand the research and editing methodology. The Committee needed to agree on whether the series was headed in the right direction before they examine individual volumes.

The Committee discussed the feasibility of examining content outlines for individual volumes. Perkins stated that the Committee probably did not possess sufficient expertise to assess the content outline of all Johnson volumes. It might be necessary to bring in experts to do this. Prof. Arnold Taylor agreed that this may be necessary, but said that he assumed the Johnson outline is based on the expertise of Department historians. He thought it would be helpful to look at individual volumes.

Prof. Jane Picker asked about the interrelationship among volumes. For example, the Johnson volume on national security policy and the volume on the administration of foreign policy includes the role of CIA and DIA (Defense Intelligence Agency). If such issues are omitted from geographical volumes, to what extent would they be cross-referenced? These questions relate directly to researchers’ ability to get at central topics.

David Mabon then briefly outlined the Johnson volume entitled “Confrontation in Southeast Asia.” He said this outline was very preliminary and that there had to be flexibility in the basic plan until the historians get into the
records. In response to a question on coverage of possible covert operations in this volume, Mabon stated that the Office of the Historian now would have access to such documentation, but the volume was planned to cover policy, not operational issues. Slany pointed out that the Historian’s Office still did not know for certain whether the CIA would adhere to this principle.

The Committee discussed access by Department historians to finding aids, particularly those of the CIA. Mabon indicated that up to now, the historians only had access to finding aids at the Presidential Libraries, not to any finding aid system at the CIA, if such exists. Herring stated that even the CIA historians do not have full access to agency finding aids. Kimball indicated that this was perhaps a problem that should be addressed within the context of the legislation.

Slany stated that materials at the Presidential Libraries were key to the series and it was important to get these documents declassified and open to public research. Yet it would be impossible for Department historians to look at every document at the Johnson Library. Fawcett indicated that all White House materials except for NSC institutional documents go to the Presidential libraries.

Kimball said that the Committee might need to make a statement on access to finding aids. David Langbart of the National Archives warned the group not to assume that every agency had good and useful finding aids. This was not the case.

Nelson indicated that the Department of Energy was another problem agency because it operated under separate legislation. Slany said that it would probably be necessary to deal with DOE separately on access to DOE documents. Perkins pointed out that this would also likely be necessary with NSA.

Van Camp maintained that the Committee could not be an advisory board and an editorial board at the same time. The most immediate need was for the Committee to be an advisory board and address the big questions for the series. She posed three central questions:

item.p: 1) What is the principal purpose of the series -- who are the users?
2) What is the nature of the historical record and how will this affect the size of the series?
3) What are the potential choke points in meeting the schedule deadlines and how can these be alleviated?

div.p: Kennedy agreed with Van Camp’s suggested approach.
A discussion ensued on the principal purpose of the Foreign Relations series. Perkins said the series had two audiences:

item.p: 1) scholars who use it as a foundation for serious research and

2) beginning graduate students. He said the series should touch on all subjects but not evenly across the board. He thought that was more important than total in-depth treatment. Herring thought that the series should provide a comprehensive overview rather than any in-depth coverage. Nelson thought some volumes deserved more in-depth treatment than others.

div.p: The preliminary sense of the Committee was that the volumes should strike a balance between presenting documentation on key issues and serving as a more comprehensive finding aid to the larger documentary record.

Picker asked about consultation with the Office of the Legal Adviser and the Law Digest. Slany responded that the Office of the Historian was trying to draw in the Legal Adviser’s records, that there was an audience for international law cases.
The open meeting of the Committee adjourned at 12:15.

quote.p: [The Committee, together with Kennedy, Slany, LaFantasie, Records Historian David Herschler, and Special Assistant Susan Povenmire continued informal discussions on the morning’s agenda during a working luncheon. No record of this session was maintained.]

list.item: Representatives of the Office of the Historian
Senior Deputy Assistant Secretary Grace Moe
Deputy Assistant Secretary G. Alfred Kennedy
Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for Information Management and Systems Operations Warren E. Littrel
James W. Moore, Assistant Archivist for Records Administration, National Archives
David Van Tassel, National Security Council

div.p: Chairman Kimball called the meeting to order and introduced Department Spokesman and Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs Margaret Tutwiler.

Ms. Tutwiler welcomed the Advisory Committee to the Department and contratulated the chairman on his election. The new legislation was challenging and difficult, but she assured the Committee that the Bureau of Public Affairs and Secretary of State were solidly behind it and stated that she would do all she could to see that it was faithfully executed. The effort would benefit from the support of Deputy Secretary Eagleburger and Under Secretary Rogers and the work of the Committee. She welcomed recommendations from the Committee.

Warren Littrel, Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for Information Management and Operations, welcomed the Committee and expressed his appreciation for the meeting. He indicated that the Office of Information Management (IM) was doing all it could to facilitate declassification of the Foreign Relations series. IM was also actively participating with the Department, other agencies, and foreign governments to
facilitate the opening of the files at a 30-year line. The Department was entering a new era in applying new technology to information management. Over 1,750,000 telegrams are handled annually; the Department’s electronic database includes over 17,000,000 documents. Through rapid communications and retrieval systems, the Secretary of State can see almost any document instantaneously. The Foreign Relations legislation comes at an important time, because it ties in with the Department’s efforts to improve information management, and fosters better Congressional and public understanding of our foreign policy goals and objectives. Littrel looked forward to the Committee’s counsel and advice.

Joe Chaddic, Director of the Historical Documents Review Division (HDR), explained the process in HDR for reviewing Foreign Relations compilations. When HDR received a compilation, it assigned a reviewer who read each page and determined the compilation’s releasability in consultation with the Department’s geographic and functional bureaus. He then sent specific documents or portions of the compilation to other agencies and foreign governments for their concurrence in the release of material which they initiated or in which they had an interest. After declassification decisions had been reached on this material, HDR sent the compilation to the NSC. Chaddic reported that in the last 12 months, HDR had received final clearances on 13 volumes, that it had completed preliminary clearances on an additional 12, and was in the process of clearing another 9 volumes. He noted that this performance represented an improvement from several years ago, and he expressed his ongoing desire to achieve the goals of the legislation.

In addition to the increased efficiency of HDR, Chaddic stated that several other developments promised to speed up Foreign Relations declassification. HDR has assigned two reviewers to the NSC to assist that agency in its review of manuscripts. He also reported that the NSC has recently agreed to accept manuscripts before foreign government clearances have been completed. This change was especially significant because it allowed manuscripts to take their place in line for NSC review while at the same time awaiting foreign government action. Chaddic also stated that United Kingdom interest in a large number of compilations led him to send a reviewer to that country to expedite U.K. clearance of 26 documents that had been pending for some time and to negotiate arrangements for future declassification. HDR had also successfully persuaded the OECD to place its documents on a 30-year declassification schedule. That organization recently agreed to release its 30-year old documents this June and every year from now on. He also reported that Alan Thompson, former Director of the Records Declassification Division at the National Archives had prepared, under contract, a draft plan to bring NATO to a
30-year declassification schedule. A major meeting is planned for May 13, 1992. Chaddic believed that with the breakup of the Soviet Union, it would be harder for NATO authorities to withhold documents for long periods of time.

Chaddic described the process for declassification of the Department’s records. When the State Department transferred the Central Files to the National Archives, it also provided guidelines for the declassification of these records. NARA then tagged and withheld all documents warranting continued protection. HDR subsequently reviewed a random sampling of untagged documents to check on the effectiveness of the system. The declassification review of the 1955-1959 block had just been completed and all but 16 percent of the classified documents had been released. HDR was currently writing the guidelines for the 1960-1963 block, having completed about 40 percent of the major regions. NARA will soon begin reviewing documents for Africa and South America. The Department of State will transfer between $150,000 and $200,000 to the National Archives to help the initial review of the 1960-1963 files. Chaddic welcomed the Committee’s interest in viewing withheld material as an opportunity for him to give credibility to the declassification process, expressing confidence that he could convince the Committee that HDR’s reasons for withholding information were valid.

Ken Rossman, Director of the Department’s Records Management Staff, described the various categories of records and record blocks in the Department, and their retirement in set blocks by periods of years. The 1960-1963 block of the Department’s Central File posed challenges. During this period, the record filing system went from the decimal to the subject-numeric system. Secret, confidential, and unclassified documents had been filed separately and would have to be combined before the files could be accessioned by the National Archives. He explained that there were 1,900 cubic feet of Central Files for the period. He added that 250 cubic feet of 30-year-old Lot files in the Top Secret vault would soon be appraised for permanent retention, along with Department post files preceding 1964.

Rossman also described what records managers were doing to make things easier 30 years from now with respect to paper records from 1964 to the present, and the electronic central files covering the years since 1973. He noted that the present system has all cable traffic on line, and that he is hopeful of eliminating routine administrative cables to reduce the burden of using the system. He mentioned his intention to persuade NARA to eventually take electronic instead of microfilm records. He indicated that digital imaging and CD-ROM were likely future applications of dissemination of the Department’s records.

Nelson asked Chaddic whether the NSC reviewed all or only portions of each compilation, to which he replied that the NSC only reviewed those documents in which it had an interest. She asked what percentage of 1940-1959 Department of State lot files were open; Chaddic did not have the figures. Nelson then inquired whether guidelines were applied to Lot files and Post files as well as to Central files; Chaddic indicated that they were.

Perkins asked if seeing the guidelines would be a good way for Committee members to understand the declassification problem. Chaddic indicated that it would be. Kimball asked if Committee members could review newly-prepared guidelines, and Chaddic said they would be more than welcome to do so. There was a further discussion of the preparation of guidelines and the process whereby they were cleared by geographic and functional bureaus.

Rosenberg asked whether there was any systematic re-review of denied documents, such as the 16 percent that could not be released from the 1955-1959 record block and whether the Committee could play a useful role in this review. Chaddic replied that the 1960-1963 guidelines were the best indication of what could now be released; nevertheless, previously denied material would not be reviewed again until an FOI request had been initiated. He said that every year or two the guidelines given to NARA for earlier record blocks were routinely modified to reflect the latest declassification decisions. These revisions were also promulgated to the Presidential Libraries. Perkins proposed following the British practice of regularly reviewing denied documents every 5 years and putting the burden of proving the need for continuing classification on those who wished the documents to remain classified. Chaddic replied that his division simply did not have the resources to implement such a periodic review.

Nelson asked what constituted foreign government information. Chaddic replied that it mostly consisted of foreign originated material or in some cases direct quotes. It did not necessarily include memoranda of conversation. He added that foreign government documents were not cleared with unfriendly governments or governments no longer in existence.

Kimball asked Chaddic if he would consult the Committee on an HDR draft report to Congress on declassification and transfer to the National Archives of the Department’s 30-year-old records due 180 days from the enactment of the legislation. Chaddic said he would have no objection to sharing the report with the Committee once the draft had been revised.

In response to Van Camp’s question of whether an accelerated pace of declassification could be maintained in the future, Chaddic replied that it could. He added, in response to Kimball’s question, that he saw no conflict between the production schedule of Foreign Relations and the declassification requirements mandated by the new legislation. Kimball then asked Chaddic whether he foresaw anything that might set back the Foreign Relations production schedule, to which he responded: “unqualifyingly no.”

In response to a further question, which prompted extended discussion among the Committee members, Chaddic stated that deciding whether to send State Department documents for clearance to other agencies was generally not difficult as other agency equity was fairly clear.

On the question of how historians would deal with electronic records in the future, Slany stated that the Office had not really had an opportunity to focus fully on the issue yet. Some years ago, the Office had experimented with on-line compiling from the Department’s electronic Central File of contemporary documents for Foreign Relations, but this effort had been preliminary and could not progress further until more could be learned about the system and the process. Mr. Herschler indicated that there were significant retrieval problems with the existing electronic Central File, and that the Department had been working on a new system for some time. He expressed the hope that an improved system for retrieval would be developed before Foreign Relations compiling began for the years 1973 and beyond.
The Committee recessed at 3:30 for a coffee break.

Kimball announced a change in the agenda. The consideration of the 1958-1960 Japan compilation would be handled by a subcommittee consisting of Glad, Herring, and Taylor who would examine the compilation and report their findings at the next meeting of the Committee. Kimball suggested that the Committee use the time after 2 p.m. on Friday to discuss and decide upon its organizational guidelines and procedures for implementing the legislation.

Picker inquired why only one session of the meeting was open while the rest were closed to the public and wondered if this was the intent of the law. Slany and Kimball explained that the Committee could go into executive session. Picker also expressed concern that as one of the new members of the Committee she would like to have additional briefings from Department of State and other officials on declassification procedures and regulations. There was a general view that the new members should have further orientation.

Slany introduced John Fawcett, Assistant Archivist for Presidential Libraries. Slany indicated that the Office of the Historian had been working closely with the Kennedy and Johnson libraries and with NARA on implementation of the legislation, and much progress had been made.

Fawcett explained that Presidential papers from this period are legally considered personal donated historical materials. Rules and regulations concerning them are to some extent more complex than those of Federal records. In addition to national security concerns regulated by Executive Order 12356, these materials are subject to deed of gift considerations. Information in Presidential materials also represents equities from a number of government agencies whose permission is required for access by Department historians.

The Presidential Libraries have worked with the Office of the Historian over the last few years in trying to streamline the procedures involved in making material available for Foreign Relations research. Previously, the processing done for Department historians was the full processing done to make the collection available for research by the public. This included reviewing the materials for donor-deed-of gift restrictions; preservation; identifying and closing marked and unmarked classified items; segregating all open and closed materials; identifying documents that have previously been declassified and marking these items; and preparing document withdrawal sheets for all closed material.

To expedite access by Department historians for Foreign Relations research, in the past few years the Presidential Libraries have performed partial processing of the materials which does not include completing all the steps necessary to open the collections to the public. Most classified material is not segregated; previously declassified items are not marked; review for donor’s deed-of-gift is not done for most documents; and the withdrawal sheets which provide the information for the researcher to make mandatory review requests are not completed. Given the current legislative mandate which accelerates the schedule for Foreign Relations, the Johnson Library might not be as responsive to full processing of foreign policy files or mandatory review requests during the 4-year period in which the Library would be giving the necessary priority to abbreviated processing for Foreign Relations research.

Glad asked why the Presidential Libraries could not simultaneously open files for public use while processing the Foreign Relations requests. Fawcett emphasized that the work done on the files for Foreign Relations researchers was geared to the individuals involved and their particular needs and clearances. Once the Department historians’ research was completed the files had to be reviewed for donor restrictions and classification, open and closed materials need to be segregated, and the withdrawal sheets must be completed.

Taylor called attention to the lag time between declassification of documents for Foreign Relations and their publication. Were the declassified documents immediately made available at the libraries and the National Archives or was it necessary to wait until publication of the volumes? Fawcett explained that they could not necessarily make a document available just because it seemed to be published in Foreign Relations, because sometimes there were differences between several copies of the same document. Guidelines were needed for them to make documents available. Herschler pointed out that a database was now in existence for the Kennedy volumes and beyond that would provide a list of which documents from Presidential Libraries had been declassified for Foreign Relations volumes, and that a printout would be sent to the Presidential libraries so that those documents could be made immediately available. Nelson asked if this list would be sent to NARA in Washington? Herschler indicated that it would.

Nelson pointed out that a number of documents in Presidential Libraries contain no classification marking. Fawcett said that the White House is the worst offender in this area and that care must be taken as some very sensitive documents have no markings. In response to Nelson’s inquiry, Fawcett indicated that all White House foreign policy documents had to be cleared with the NSC.

Perkins wondered whether archival staff at some of the libraries where processing had been substantially completed --such as the Truman or Eisenhower Libraries -- could be transferred to the Johnson. Fawcett explained that the government cannot precipitously fire people or require them to move, except at great expense. Once someone resigns or retires the slot can then be moved. He then provided the following breakdown of the total number of pages of classified material at the libraries:
Fawcett also said that there were still a small number of documents at the Roosevelt Library that remained classified. The older ones were mainly intelligence documents.

There was a long discussion of what constitituted equities in a document. In response to an inquiry by Picker, Chaddic said he did not think that there was any written definition. In general, equity could be defined as that information in a document in which another agency has a legitimate concern. George Chalou said NARA’s practice was to return to the agency of origin to determine equity. Kimball expressed surprise that the State Department did not let the originating agency decide equity and that there were not articulated procedures. Chaddic said other agencies trusted the State Department to protect their equity. The documents that an agency originated were always returned to it for declassification. David Langbart explained that when one government agency talked about the activities of another government agency the second agency had an equity in the document of the first agency.

Kimball raised the question of whether the Department’s current procedure was making declassification more difficult. Why not just let the originating agency define which other agencies had equity? Chaddic pointed out that all documents in Foreign Relations have State Department equity and that the process would be slowed down if the other agency equity decision were deferred to each agency. Also, frequently when State sends a document to another agency it points out that the State Department does not object to its declassification and this helps facilitate the other agency decision.

In response to a question from Nelson, Fawcett confirmed that all White House documents were sent to the NSC, after being cleared by State or CIA, as appropriate. David Van Tassel of the NSC staff said that this is because NSC plays a coordinator role.

Kimball asked what in addition to the interagency agreements the Department Historian was now negotiating with other agencies would be helpful to the Presidential Libraries in their access and declassification responsibilities? Fawcett emphasized that working with the Foreign Relations historians would be a full-time job for the Presidential Library staffs. A good interagency agreement would facilitate the job, as would any procedures that would shorten the time Department historians spend at the libraries. He also discussed the special circumstances of the Nixon materials. President Nixon retained a veto over who could see the files.

Committee members continued to express concern over suspension of work at the libraries on mandatory review requests in order to meet the Foreign Relations schedule. Nancy Smith pointed out that at the Kennedy Library mandatory review was suspended for a time. Nelson asked about conducting systematic declassification review at the libraries. Fawcett said that the NSC conducted such a review at the Eisenhower Library some years ago and was talking about sending someone to the Johnson Library.

Kimball asked if the Presidential Libraries used State Department guidelines and, if so, how effective they were. Fawcett explained that because Presidential materials were so complex, it was difficult to apply the Department’s guidelines. Chaddic stated that the Department’s guidelines, nevertheless, were the best in the Federal government.

Picker inquired about secret treaties and how the public was informed when one was declassified? Slany noted that in the past they had been declassified and printed in Foreign Relations. The Historian’s Office would try to strike a deal with the Department’s Legal Adviser to ensure that they are included in the series. It was also true that some executive agreements were not sent to NARA. Kimball said that the Committee would address this problem.

Michael McReynolds of the National Archives’ Civil Reference Division said a few words about NARA’s move to the new building in College Park. He indicated that the 1960-1963 State Department records would remain at Suitland until the move was completed.
It was agreed that some representatives from NARA would return on Friday. The meeting recessed at 4:50 p.m.

list.item: Representatives of the Office of the Historian
Senior Deputy Assistant Secretary Grace Moe
Deputy Assistant Secretary G. Alfred Kennedy
J. Kenneth McDonald, Central Intelligence Agency
David Van Tassel, National Security Council

div.p: Chairman Kimball convened the meeting at 9:12 a.m. The first order of business was a security briefing by Jacqueline Baker of the Division of Information Security, Office of Procedural Security, Bureau of Diplomatic Security (DS/PRD/IF). After considerable description of standard security procedures, Baker distributed a form in which the members undertook not to willfully reveal any classified information received by them as a result of their Committee duties. In reply to an expression of concern by the Committee regarding the impact of this undertaking, Baker emphasized that it would have reference only to information received as a direct result of their Committee activities. The government must prove that an attempt had been made to purposefully circumvent the non-disclosure agreement. To her knowledge, no request for publication submitted under the terms of this agreement had ever been disapproved.

Kimball then proposed, and the Committee agreed, to add to the morning’s agenda, without deleting any other items, a presentation by David Langbart of NARA on records retirement and administration issues.

J. Kenneth McDonald, Chief of the History Staff of the Central Intelligence Agency, then described the reorganization of the Agency’s Historical Review Program according to new policies that the Director of Central Intelligence (DCI), Robert Gates, outlined in a speech to the Oklahoma Press Association on February 21 (copies distributed to the Committee). The DCI has appointed David Gries, former Vice Chariman of the National Intelligence Council, Director of CIA’s Center for the Study of Intelligence (CSI), which will be expanded to about 40 people, and placed in the Office of the DCI. In CSI a new Historical Review Group (HRG) of about 20 people will be responsible for systematic declassification review of all CIA records over 30 years old (with the exception of certain operational files), as well as for the review of all National Intelligence Estimates on the former Soviet Union over 10 years old, collections of CIA records on special topics (such as specific covert operations), and CIA records that the State Department proposes to publish in compiled volumes of the Foreign Relations series. (Mandatory Review, FOIA, and Privacy cases will continue to be handled by CIA’s Directorate of Administration, as before.) McDonald emphasized that the DCI has directed the Historical Review Program to have a “bias toward declassification,” and that records reviewed under it will be declassified unless their disclosure reasonably can be expected to cause damage to the national security. He noted that since 1984 the CIA has declassified and transferred to the National Archives almost all -- some 4800 cubic feet -- of its Office of Strategic Services (OSS) operational records.

The CIA History Staff, expanded to about 15 people in CSI, will select groups of records for systematic review, assemble documents on special topics for review, and locate and arrange access to CIA records for State Department historians compiling Foreign Relations volumes. The expansion of the History Staff will provide more resources for CIA’s support of State Department historians, as required by the new legislation. McDonald noted that the formal agreement concerning access procedures will be concluded by the April 25 legislative deadline. In fact, the CIA History Staff began its voluntary program of providing direct access for State historians to Agency records in January 1991. In the future these historians will have access not only to Agency records, but also to finding aids, in so far as comprehensive finding aids are available.

McDonald is co-chairman of a DCI Task Force that is preparing new Historical Review Program declassification guidelines to govern the review of CIA’s records, including those proposed for publication in the Foreign Relations volumes. Documents that might previously have been withheld from declassification because they fell into a category automatically eligible for protection, will now be reviewed individually, and denied only if specific damage to national security can be shown. McDonald stated his high optimism about the total impact of the changes he had outlined.

McDonald emphasized that relations between CIA’s History Staff and Department of State historians had been excellent since he had joined CIA and the History Staff in 1981. Since that time, he had approved every Department of State request for historians to have direct access to CIA records at the History Staff, as well as every request for State historians’ access to CIA classified documentation at the several Presidential libraries. Since January 1991, at State’s request after the flap over the Iran 1951-1954 volume, the CIA History Staff has systematically arranged direct access to Agency records for State historians compiling Foreign Relations volumes. These arrangements have worked well, although the History Staff has lacked the personnel needed to process quickly the very large number of documents that State historians have requested.

Mary McAuliffe, Deputy Chief of the History Staff, spoke next, calling CIA’s new policy of openness and rules governing historical declassification “revolutionary.” She cautioned, however, that CIA records are voluminous and decentralized; it is tough to find records and even difficult to find out “how they are kept.” The declassification process will be aided by the creation of a new information database.

Rosenberg asked if the April 25 deadline imposed by the legislation for reaching a CIA-State access agreement would be met, and McDonald replied that it would. The coordination, he explained, would be managed through the Center for the Study of Intelligence. McDonald noted that although Department compilers since 1977 have had direct access to all CIA records at the Presidential Libraries, CIA in the past has required that these libraries send copies of documents selected by State historians to the History Staff for CIA review (and in some cases, denial of copies) before they can be released to the State Department. This procedure will be revised, of course, to conform to the new legislation.

In response to Nelson’s question about possible obstruction to the new program by “some elements of CIA,” McDonald pointed out that for records under the Historical Review Program, the DCI had transferred declassification authority from the originating offices in CIA to the Director of CSI. Noting her concern with the use of annuitants (retired employees) in State’s declassification program and possible conflicts of interest, Nelson expressed the hope that CIA would not use annuitants in its new HRG. McDonald explained that CIA would in fact use both GS-13 staff employees as well as annuitants as HRG reviewers. In general, however, he did not expect the program to engage retired officers who had worked in previous CIA declassification programs.

Perkins asked about the procedure for preparing the document summaries as specified in the legislation. McDonald replied that while he believed that summaries would fill a useful role, there would no doubt be instances when even a summary of a highly sensitive document might not be acceptable to the CIA.

Van Camp asked what the CIA had already transferred to the National Archives under the Historical Review Program. McDonald pointed out that two important early histories declassified and released in 1989 and 1990 had since been published by Penn State Press, and that some 10,000 pages of documents related to these histories had been transferred to NARA in 1991. George Chalou of NARA offered his opinion that the CIA histories transferred to NARA were useful, but the latest series, the Historical Source documents, were of minimal research quality. Noting that DCI Gates had characterized the transfers so far as “meager,” McDonald gave his view that the DCI’s new policies, calling for a bias toward declassification and a presumption for disclosure, would make a substantial difference in the amount of material declassified and transferred to the National Archives.

In response to a question by Picker, McDonald said that some documents relating to such subjects as counterintelligence, human sources, and methods of handling defectors, would be unlikely to be declassified. He did expect, however, that CIA’s new guidelines would permit for the first time the declassification of significant information concerning covert operations up to the early 1960s.
The Committee recessed for a coffee break at 10:35.
After the break, the Committee continued their discussion with Kenneth McDonald, Chief of the CIA History Staff.

In response to Herring’s question, McDonald noted that while the CIA has no central index to its records (because of security compartmentalization), he expected the new Historical Review Program to prepare all-Agency finding aids. The moratorium since last December on Department of State historians’ research at the CIA History Staff will continue until State and CIA conclude their memorandum of understanding concerning the new access procedures. He noted that the CIA History Staff was using the respite to process a large backlog of records requested in State historians’ visits over the past year, and there was no point in asking CIA components for more documents until the new access procedures are in place. To speed its expansion, he explained, the History Staff hoped to recruit several new historians from inside CIA who already have the necessary clearances. Until the History Staff has additional historians, support staff, and larger quarters, it will probably continue to ask that only one State historian visit at a time.

Glad asked whether the new law required meetings if differences existed between the Department Historian and the other agencies. McDonald expected that such meetings would be a sensible way to solve problems. Glad also inquired whether notes in the printed volumes will indicate if important material had been denied, or the integrity of the record was compromised. Slany remarked that the Historian’s Office would try to include as much of an explanation as possible, but that it had to be guided by the originating agencies.
Kimball asked how much indication the volumes would give if documents are deleted. Slany said that would have to be worked out with the originating agency.

Kimball asked if CIA documents from the Presidential Libraries will still have to be reviewed by CIA before Department historians can get copies. McDonald responded that CIA will reorganize -- and probably eliminate -- that step to conform to the new legislation. Kimball also asked whether access was limited to specific geographic areas. McDonald replied that the History Staff would arrange full and complete access for State historians to all CIA records relevant to the volume being compiled. Nancy Smith commented that other classifying agencies also restricted access to specific areas. Kimball noted that the Committee will probably raise the issue of agency review of copies of documents selected by Department historians prior to compilation of volumes with respect to both the CIA and the NSC, since the Committee is concerned about the delay caused by this extra step.

While McDonald had reported that Department historians would have full and complete access to relevant records 26 years old or older, it was noted that Department historians will soon be researching records of the Johnson administration, through 1968. The question was raised whether CIA would restrict access to 1967 and 1968 records. McDonald responded that although it was the new legislation -- and not the CIA or the History Staff -- that specified the 26-year access limit, he personally expects CIA to do more than the law requires, since DCI Gates clearly wants the Agency to be helpful and forthcoming.

Asked about CIA’s relations with foreign intelligence agencies, McDonald explained that CIA cannot release foreign government information without permission of that government. He pointed out that the British only officially acknowledge the existence of their intelligence services after 30 years, and that they (and most other countries) never declassify and release any intelligence records at all. The CIA’s release of its OSS operational records, and its commitment to systematic declassification review of all records over 30 years old, are in fact unprecedented anywhere else in the world.
McDonald left copies of DCI Gates’ Oklahoma speech for the Committee.

David Langbart of NARA then recommended that the Committee pay more attention to records management procedures and current recordkeeping practices in the Department. He described the Department of State electronic records system for its Central File, created in mid-1973. He stated that the electronic system provides fairly good coverage of records but some material does not go into the system. Some files of top-level officials are preserved as paper files but are not in the electronic index. He noted that this does not represent a real change; it has been true for many years that some important records were not put in the Central File but were maintained separately as Lot files.

Ken Rossman said the Department’s Records Management staff is looking at the system more closely to examine such questions as whether the system is overloaded with too much material lacking permanent interest and at the usability of records on microfilm and microfiche. In response to a question from Van Camp, he said he thought they needed to look at the electronic mail issue; he was sure that retaining these records would be, and probably is already, a problem.

Kimball returned to the issue of the Presidential Libraries. He said the Committee is concerned about Fawcett’s statement on Thursday that the Johnson Library might not be as responsive to full processing of foreign policy files or mandatory review requests during the 4-year period in which the Library would be giving the necessary priority to access by Department historians for Foreign Relations research. Fawcett stated that the conflict between mandatory review and the preparation of records for Foreign Relations research is real. The problem is one of resources. The Presidential Libraries are adjusting their work load and reallocating resources.

Kimball did not believe the Committee would accept an “either/or” solution. There were requirements for mandatory review and also statutory requirements for release and publication of documents. Fawcett said these requirements are not the only considerations in opening personal papers. Nelson said that McGeorge Bundy’s papers, for example, fell under the requirements of the executive order. Fawcett explained that the government controlled the information (as compared with the copy of the document in a personal papers collection), and the executive order applied to the originator of the information and tells archivists at the Presidential Libraries to treat certain documents in these personal papers collections as classified if they contain national security information. The declassification of such documents was necessary in addition to a review for donor restrictions.

Kimball argued that the law required a review of Department of State records after 30 years. Fawcett insisted it did not apply to copies of Department records in personal papers collections in the Presidential Libraries. Kimball asked why there was no compulsion to review documents for declassification after 30 years? Fawcett responded that the Presidential Libraries have an ongoing mandatory review program, but he did not have sufficient resources to ensure meeting the Department of State Foreign Relations schedule while maintaining complete processing of foreign policy files and the mandatory review program in those libraries preparing for or assisting in Foreign Relations research.

Nelson pointed out that publication of Foreign Relations will help the libraries with mandatory review by making more records available to everyone. In response to questions as to whether the Presidential Libraries could combine preparation of files for Department of State historians with related mandatory review requests, Fawcett said that was not feasible. Smith briefly explained what was involved in the processing of files for researchers and noted that the Presidential Libraries had undertaken partial processing for Department historians to provide accelerated special access for Foreign Relations research.

Herring noted that there was a trade-off between Department of State access and regular processing. Nelson stated that the Committee could not be in the position of approving that trade-off. The statute has been passed; NARA has to carry out its part. Fawcett stated that the Johnson Library was better prepared than the Kennedy Library for Department researchers in that more processing has been done. Kimball stated that the Committee would probably express its unhappiness with the situation.

Fawcett stressed that the problem is one of resources. NARA has been giving priority to the building of Archives II and does not have all the money it needs to cover the move. It would be appropriate for the Department of State to cover some of the libraries’ cost of preparing records for Department research. In this regard the Department has been exploring with the Presidential Libraries a reimbursable agreement for $14,000 to cover the cost of an archives technician at the Johnson Library until the end of the fiscal year. He pointed out that the Library needs to hire people in advance because of the time necessary to obtain security clearances for new staff.
The Committee recessed at noon for luncheon.

head.hi: Luncheon Meeting with Under Secretary Rogers

div.p: Under Secretary of State for Management John F. W. Rogers greeted the Committee on behalf of the Secretary and assured the Committee of his own and the Department’s commitment to implementing the October 28, 1991 statute. He stressed that he considered the statute to be of great importance. He thanked the Committee members for agreeing to serve, noting that this activity took time away from their own endeavors. Mr. Rogers indicated that he was not with the Department when the legislation was under consideration, which he felt would be an advantage in that implementing the legislation posed no difficulties of consistency or inconsistency. He stated that everyone under his direction would be required to do everthing necessary to implement the new statute.

Chairman Kimball expressed the Committee’s appreciation for Under Secretary Rogers’ support. The Committee had been very pleased with the support of Rogers’ predecessor, Ivan Selin, and the improved responsiveness of the Department to the Committee’s concerns during the past year. He believed that the legislation offered an opportunity to improve the Foreign Relations series and looked forward to working with the Department in the implementation of the statute.

During the ensuing luncheon, Under Secretary Rogers and Committee members engaged in discussion ranging from budget, resource, and organizational issues attendant to implementation of the legislation, to the impact of recent changes in the former Soviet Union on the historical record.

Kimball inquired if the Committee wished to discuss the issue of publication of supplemental documentation to Foreign Relations, Iran, 1951-1954. Herring saw little point in preparing a supplement on Iran, as the legislation established a process to prevent such a situation in the future. Rosenberg indicated that the CIA should be urged to identify as many of the documents on Iran not published in the volume and work out some way of having them released. Kimball said that Department historians should assess these materials and deal with the manner in which they should be released. Slany suggested that the Committee recommend that the matter be resolved quickly.

The question arose of delaying the publication of a volume, such as on Indonesia, in order to get more documents released by the CIA. LaFantasie said there was a trade-off; delay would affect the production schedule. The documents would have to be worth such a trade-off. Glad expressed concern that the production schedule for the volumes not compromise comprehensiveness. She referred to the proposed size limitation of 800 pages for each Johnson volume. Slany indicated that size affects the processing of volumes. Selection standards must be maintained, although the fewer documents selected, the faster the processing of the volumes would be. LaFantasie said that the Office of the Historian would have to be flexible on page counts.

Rosenberg again raised the issue of the plan for publishing the foreign policy record of the Johnson administration. It would not be prudent to continue to shrink the published record to meet time constraints even while the universe of documentation expands. It might be necessary to consider supplements to the planned Johnson volumes. Perkins, however, stated that the planned Johnson publications would meet the purpose of the series; he would not want to see the schedule sacrificed in order to publish a few more volumes or pages of documents.

Van Camp urged that the Committee focus on the Department’s plan at the next meeting. Picker also urged that the next meeting include a discussion of the issue of the ultimate disposition and use of the larger foreign policy record. Kimball said these would be major agenda items at the next meeting. He asked the Historian to circulate current plans and previous reports to Committee members in advance of that meeting.
The Committee adjourned and reconvened in executive session at 2:30.

The Committee reviewed and discussed the items that it wished to take under consideration, to include on the next meeting’s agenda, and/or to present in a report to the Department on the results of this meeting.

item.p: A. Establishment of Subcommittees
1. Prof. Herring, Prof. Glad, and Prof. Taylor will review 1958-1960 Vol. XVII, Japan with particular attention to the DOS declassification review decisions.
2. Prof. Kimball and Prof. Perkins will review 1955-1957, Vol. XXIII, Part 2, Korea and the declassification review thereof.
3. Ms. Van Camp and Prof. Rosenberg will review the Department declassification review guidelines.
4. Prof. Nelson and Prof. Picker will review the interagency agreements for access by department historians.
B. The Van Camp Report
The Committee reviewed Ms. Van Camp’s summary of the Committee’s views on the principles and procedures to be followed in future meetings. It was to be taken up again at the next meeting.
C. Production Progress Report

The Committee was pleased that there appeared full agreement on the Production Schedule for the accelerated series. The Committee would like to see a progress report from the Department at the next meeting on how well the schedule is being implemented.
D. Dissemination of the Foreign Relations Production Schedule

The Committee reiterated its desire that the Foreign Relations Production Schedule (dated March 25, 1992) now be disseminated (published) by the appropriate organs of the constitutent societies and that updates be published annually thereafter.
E. Streamline Historians’ Access to Agency Records

The Committee was going to recommend that the agreements that the Department intended to conclude with other agencies regarding access by Department historians include some sort of “blanket” clearance that allowed receipt of copies of documents without an extra step for preliminary agency screening and review.
F. The Size and Scope of the Johnson Administration Subseries

The Committee reiterated its concern about the planned size and scope of the Foreign Relations series documenting the Johnson years. The ambitious time schedule and the “800-page model” of selectivity will be put at the head of the agenda for the next meeting.
G. Presidential Library Reimbursement

The Committee expressed concern about the real or apparent conflict between Presidential Library priority service of Department historians and the research needs of private historians. Because of the special nature of the Presidential papers, this aspect of the access issue was a State Department problem. The Committee wished to recommend to the Department that it consider allocating resources to mitigate the problem.
H. Opening of the Foreign Affairs Record

The Committee wished to encourage the early opening of the foreign affairs records of the various agencies. A report from the CIA on its priorities for such opening would be looked forward to. The Committee would like to recommend that CIA records on covert actions in Guatemala in 1954 and Iran in 1953 be assigned a very high priority and that a report be made to the Committee at its May meeting.
I. Identifying Volumes for Committee Review

The Committee had no way on its own to determine which volumes needed its review. It would be left to the Historian and his staff to identify which volumes were in trouble and needed advice of the Committee.
J. Treaties and Executive Agreements

The Committee, and particularly Prof. Picker, were concerned about the inclusion in the printed record of secret treaties and agreements. The Historian agreed to make a report on these records and their inclusion in the series.
K. Records Management Report
The Committee looked forward to Mr. Rossman’s report on Department records management procedures.
L. Committee Communications
The Commmittee would like to facilitate communication with the Executive Secretary by E-Mail and fax. It urged that these links would greatly facilitate the work of the Committee.
M. Open Committee Meetings

The Committee favored as much openness to the public of their meetings as possible. It urged that the first portion of the next (May) meeting be open to the public. It appreciated the reports received at this meeting from various government officers, but felt that far fewer briefings would be necessary at the next meeting.
N. Next Meetings

The Committee felt that a May meeting would be urgently required. It asked the Executive Secretary to poll members and set the most convenient date. A possible August meeting was discussed, but no decisions was reached. The Department was asked to determine what the legal requirements for meetings were under the October 28, 1991 statute.

div.p: The Committee adjourned at 3:30 p.m.
